title: Commander Keen Pixeling Videos (2nd Video Added)
content:
[img]http://dylangallagher.googlepages.com/mortlame.png[/img]
[url=http://dylangallagher.googlepages.com/mortyman.rar]Video #1[/url]
This is just my first video. I drew Mortimer from scratch without using any references or anything. There's no color limit, so it may not teach you a whole lot about working with color restrictions, but you still might learn a thing or two about how I pixel in Paint.

[img]http://dylangallagher.googlepages.com/egathingwithbilly.gif[/img]
[url=http://gnosticus.spatang.com/billypixel.rar]Video #2[/url]
Second video. In this one I actually use the EGA palette. Sorry for the filesize and length, but Camtasia is being a big meanie.

You're gonna need the [url=http://download.techsmith.com/tscc/tscc.exe]Techsmith Codec[/url] to watch these. (Thanks Grafix)[center]TOUGH GUYS DON'T FOLLOW FADS[/center]

title: Re: Commander Keen Pixeling Videos
content: I have a similar problem, and it's because the download stops after 250KB and the browser (Firefox), *for some strange reason* marks the download as successful. The file size is greater than 5 MB, obviously there must be a problem with the server where it's located.[hr][img]http://img136.imageshack.us/img136/983/vegetableswk2.gif[/img]

content:

title: Re: Commander Keen Pixeling Videos
content:
Good stuff. Much respect to the adept palette-grabbing. I get lost in 16-bit and higher modes. 4- and 8-bit seem limited to many, but I work well with a few boundaries.

What did you use to capture this video?

title: Re: Commander Keen Pixeling Videos
content:
I'm pretty sure I don't have that TSCC codec installed, I don't think I ever even heard of it, but the video plays just fine with [url=http://www.videolan.org/vlc/]VLC media player[/url].
Well, the right side seems to be cut of, but that's probably because the video was cropped a bit.

As for the actual subject, watching the video makes me think MS Paint is cramping your style a bit. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
Having the smoothness of (for instance) Photoshop's tools helps make shadowing and lighting much easier.
The use of layers helps making large changes more easily without having to redo as much work because of that.
Of course doing every pixel by hand is a skill you may prefer.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: yay
content: Thanks, Allstories. That was fun to watch.

title: Re: yay
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]4- and 8-bit seem limited to many, but I work well with a few boundaries.[hr][/quote]

Yeah, me too. Even when I'm able to use as many colors as I want, I usually use certain values for red, green and blue. Mainly just 0, 50, 100, etc, and then for more detail, I use values like 25, 75, and so on. (I know that's a bit odd for color values, since its base 16 (?), but it's easier to remember.)-Genius314
[url=http://planetck.spatang.com]PlanetCK[/url]

title: ah ha!
content: The part where you shaded the shirt was really the best part of the video... is there any set of pseudo-rules you use when deciding what width to make each section of shaded color? Maybe it's due to the smaller size of tiles/structures in KeenMods, but I feel that whenever I try to incorporate the next level of shading after straight checkerboarding, it comes out looking awful--but seeing you do it made it look very natural. What's the scoop?
